newsitem.title: JAPAN: Oracle unit says Intel ties to help NC system.
newsitem.headline: Oracle unit says Intel ties to help NC system.

text.p: Network Computer Inc, a wholly owned Oracle Corp unit, said on Thursday that a closer relationship with Intel Corp is helping it promote a new standard of stripped-down personal and business use computers.

Network Computer president Jerry Baker told a news conference in Tokyo that proposals by companies such as Oracle to build computers based on totally new chip architecture had made personal computer manufacturers wary about becoming involved.
"It took a change in our strategy...not only to use Intel architecture, but also to make a commitment to continue to explore new features in Intel development architecture," Baker said.
"It is a comfort factor that is involved," he added.
Baker said the change in strategy will help personal computer makers jump into the so-called network computer (NC) camp because Intel chip architecture is familiar to them.
The supporters of network computers originally planned to use only ARM microprocessors to build the NC computers, but changed that strategy and added Intel architecture in the fall of 1996.
Intel publicly supported network computers for the first time on Wednesday during the Oracle Open World exhibition in Tokyo.

Oracle chief executive Larry Ellison has touted the advantages of NCs, saying they are simple, inexpensive and easy for everyone to build, while conventional PCs are "expensive, complex and unreliable".
Big Japanese PC makers, already losing money in cut-price competition, are holding back on deciding whether to jump into the NC hardware business due to concerns of low profitability.
But three Japanese makers not involved in PC production -- Funai Electric, Akai Electric Co and Uniden Corp -- have agreed to make NC terminals based on Oracle's design.
Oracle expects NC terminals to be sold for $295 to $795 per unit, or "as cheap as phones", as Ellison said.
Oracle, International Business Machines Corp and Sun Microsystems Inc are the three core companies promoting network computers.
NC terminals are expected to be launched in Japan around August, possibly by Funai.
